Slides.Title: What is Object Detection?
Slides.ImageIdea: A scene with various objects like cars, people, and signs, each with a box around them.
Slides.ConceptExplanation: Object detection is about finding and identifying objects in pictures.
Slides.DeepExplanation: Imagine you have a picture of a busy street. Object detection helps a computer find and name things like cars, people, and traffic lights in that picture.
Slides.GraphIdea: A simple diagram showing input image and output with labeled boxes.
Slides.Example: Detecting cars and pedestrians in a street scene for autonomous driving.
Slides.Content: Object detection helps computers see and understand what's in a picture. It's like when you look at a photo and can point out a car, a person, or a tree. This is important for things like self-driving cars, which need to know what's around them to drive safely.

Slides.Title: Two-Stage Detection: Faster R-CNN
Slides.ImageIdea: Two-step process diagram: first finding regions, then classifying them.
Slides.ConceptExplanation: Two-stage detection first finds possible object areas, then checks what they are.
Slides.DeepExplanation: Think of it like a treasure hunt: first, you look for places where treasure might be hidden, then you check each spot to see if there's actually treasure there.
Slides.GraphIdea: Flowchart showing region proposal followed by classification.
Slides.Example: Faster R-CNN is used in security cameras to detect intruders.
Slides.Content: Two-stage detection methods like Faster R-CNN work by first finding areas in an image that might contain objects. Then, they take a closer look at these areas to figure out exactly what the objects are. This method is very accurate but can be slower than other methods.

Slides.Title: Single-Stage Detection: YOLO
Slides.ImageIdea: Grid over an image with detected objects highlighted.
Slides.ConceptExplanation: Single-stage detection finds and identifies objects in one go.
Slides.DeepExplanation: Imagine you have a magic camera that can instantly tell you what's in a picture without needing to look twice. That's what YOLO does with images.
Slides.GraphIdea: Diagram showing input image directly leading to detected objects.
Slides.Example: YOLO is used in drones to quickly identify objects while flying.
Slides.Content: Single-stage detection methods like YOLO are super fast because they look at the whole image at once to find and identify objects. This makes them great for real-time applications, like drones or robots that need to make quick decisions.

Slides.Title: Key Point-Based Detection: CenterNet
Slides.ImageIdea: Image with key points marked on objects.
Slides.ConceptExplanation: Key point-based detection uses important points to find objects.
Slides.DeepExplanation: It's like connecting the dots: you find key points on an object, and then you can see the whole shape and know what it is.
Slides.GraphIdea: Diagram showing key points on objects and how they form bounding boxes.
Slides.Example: CenterNet is used in sports to track players by their key points.
Slides.Content: Key point-based detection methods like CenterNet find important points on objects to figure out what they are. This method is useful for detecting small or crowded objects, like players in a sports game.

Labs.Title: Lab 1: Understanding Object Detection
Labs.Goal: Learn how to identify objects in images using bounding boxes.

Dataset.description: A small dataset with images of simple objects like apples and books.

CodeFiles.description: Python script to load images and draw bounding boxes around detected objects.

Labs.Title: Lab 2: Speed vs. Accuracy in Detection
Labs.Goal: Compare the speed and accuracy of two-stage and single-stage detection methods.

Dataset.description: Images of street scenes with various objects like cars and pedestrians.

CodeFiles.description: Python script to run and compare Faster R-CNN and YOLO on the dataset.

Labs.Title: Lab 3: Key Point Detection
Labs.Goal: Explore how key point-based detection works and its advantages.

Dataset.description: Images of sports players with key points marked.

CodeFiles.description: Python script to detect key points on objects and draw bounding boxes.
